greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Total number of smallest parts in all partitions of n that do not contain 1 as a part.
comment: Total number of smallest parts in all partitions of the head of the last section of the set of partitions of n.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
G. E. Andrews, The number of smallest parts in the partitions of n
A. Folsom and K. Ono, The spt-function of Andrews
F. G. Garvan, Congruences for Andrews' spt-function modulo 32760 and extension of Atkin's Hecke-type partition congruences
F. G. Garvan, Congruences for Andrews' spt-function modulo powers of 5, 7 and 13
K. Ono, Congruences for the Andrews spt-function
formula: G.f.: Sum_{i>=2} x^i/(1 - x^i) * Product_{j>=i} 1/(1 - x^j). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 03 2017
example: For n = 8 the seven partitions of 8 that do not contain 1 as a part are:
Note that in every partition the smallest parts are shown between parentheses. The total number of smallest parts is 1+2+1+1+1+2+4 = 12, so a(8) = 12.
mathematica: Table[s = Select[IntegerPartitions[n], ! MemberQ[#, 1] &]; Plus @@ Table[Count[x, Min[x]], {x, s}], {n, 50}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Oct 19 2011 *)

b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = If[n==0 || i<2, 0, b[n, i-1] + Sum[If[n== i*j, j, b[n-i*j, i-1]], {j, 1, n/i}]]; a[n_] := b[n, n]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 60}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 12 2015, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
program: return sum(list(p).count(min(p)) for p in Partitions(n,min_part=2))
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Oct 19 2011
ext: More terms from _D. S. McNeil_, Oct 19 2011
